isis.stitle: DT-466E and 530E Diesel Engine Diagnostics (1995) - ELECTRONIC CONTROL SYSTEM DIAGNOSTICS - CIRCUIT FUNCTION AND DIAGNOSTICS - TACHOMETER INPUT CIRCUITS

svcsubproc.title: CIRCUIT FUNCTIONS
svcsubproc.para: The ECM (Electronic Control Module) provides the VPM (Vehicle Personality Module) with a 0 - 12 volt digital signal that indicates engine speed. The VPM buffers this signal and supplies the instrument panel with a signal to operate the tachometer. The frequency sent by the ECM is 1/5th of the actual engine RPM.

svcsubproc.title: FAULT DETECTION MANAGEMENT
svcsubproc.para: The VPM can detect if the TACH signal is not being received from the ECM and will set a fault code to indicate loss of communication. No fault detection is available for communication between the VPM and the instrument panel.

svcsubproc.title: EXTENDED DESCRIPTION TACHOMETER INPUT CIRCUIT
svcsubproc.para:
Refer to the circuit diagram Figure 3.140
for the following discussion.

svcsubproc.title: Tachometer Input Signal
svcsubproc.para: The ECM receives signals from the CMP sensor and calculates engine speed (rpm). The ECM sends the calculated engine speed as a digital TACH signal from ECM connector 36 (circuit 97D) to the VPM at connector (381) terminal 4.
The VPM buffers the TACH signal received from ECM and sends a pulse width modulated (PMW) signal to the Speedometer/ Tachometer unit at center I/P connector (27).

svcsubproc.title: Engine Speed Signal To Prolink EST
svcsubproc.para: Engine rpm can be monitored using the Prolink Electronic Service Tool (EST) connected to the EST connector (384). It is important to note that the signal is transmitted through different circuits.

The engine speed signal read by the Prolink EST comes from the ECM, but is sent from ECM terminals 9 and 28, through the DCL (+) and DCL (-) circuits to the VPM, then through the ATA (+) and ATA (-) circuits, to the EST connector (384).

svcsubproc.title: ECM DIAGNOSTICS
svcsubproc.para: If the CMP signal is not received and processed by the ECM, the engine will not start. If the engine is running, but the tachometer does not operate (or operates improperly), there are two tests to further isolate the problem.

svcsubproc.title: Testing Speedometer/Tachometer Cluster
svcsubproc.para: With the key ON and engine OFF, the Speedometer/Tachometer unit, located in the instrument panel, will perform a self-test, checking the tachometer gauge and the speedometer/tachometer control unit. Refer to Service Manual, Group 08, Instruments for the appropriate section for information on performing this test.

svcsubproc.title: KOER Tach Buffer Test
svcsubproc.para: The KOER - Tach Buffer Test must be run when engine speed is greater than 1250 rpm. This test checks the circuit (97D) between the ECM and VPM for open or short (high or low) circuit condition. It also checks the internal VPM buffer circuit for open or short (high or low) conditions. If a defect is found, Flash Code 233 is set.

svcsubproc.title: Flash Code 233
svcsubproc.para: This code is set during the KOER Tach Buffer Test if:

item.para: Engine speed is less than 1250 rpm.
Circuit 97D is open or shorted (high or low) between the ECM and VPM causing the VPM to receive either no signal or an invalid signal.
The VPM internal buffering circuit is defective.

svcsubproc.title: Corrective Action
svcsubproc.para: If the tachometer doesn't work and:

step1.para:
A. The Speedometer/Tachometer Self-Test does not indicate a defect, perform Testing Circuit 97AR Figure 3.141.
. If the self-test revealed a defect, follow service manual recommended corrective action.

B. The Tach Buffer KOER test does not set a fault code, then check circuit 97AR between VPM connector (381) and I/P connector (27) for open or short (high or low) circuit by performing Testing Circuit 97AR Figure 3.141.
.

C. If the Tach Buffer KOER test does set Flash code 233, perform Testing ECM/VPM Tachometer Circuit Figure 3.142.
.
